snippet.title: Take me back to the good old days
snippet.content: LAST week I let Ed Sheeran take me "way back when", listening to his hit song Castle on the Hill inspired me to detour into my childhood memories. This week the Daily has done the same thing with their fantastic series of lift-outs celebrating 50 years of the Sunshine Coast. Every day something twigs my memory, such as Thursday with the smiling figure of Cliff Butt on the cover. Not only was Cliff the legend of the Maroochydore business centre with his supermarket, I actually worked for him carrying groceries when I was a little fat kid hungry for pocket money. That photo brought back memories of Mr Butt as well as the other job I had to keep me well fed with Coke and barbecue chips - being a paper boy for Reid's Newsagency at Cotton Tree. Mr Reid was really good to me while I was a little scared of Mrs Reid when we used to debate how many papers I had sold because what I thought she owed me and what she thought she was willing to pay was always slightly askew. But, like the Butts, the Reids were legends around the area in that era - wonderful business people with great customer service. So what was I doing apart from carrying groceries and short-changing customers in front of the Maroochy Hotel selling them late edition Telegraphs - I was in Grade 4 at Eudlo School. That was my first year in the "big room" for grades 4-7 after coming out of Mrs Topp's "little room" for grades 1-3. The only teachers were the principal, Jim Johnson, who taught in the "big room", and Mrs Topp but it was a wonderful way to grow up, drinking sun-warmed school milk, singing God Save the Queen as the flag went up the pole and every Friday singing Life is Great in the Sunshine State, as well as getting put on "pine cone duty" more often than most. Frank Nicklin was the Premier of Queensland. He was a pineapple farmer from Palmwoods and good friends with my mum so we used to get a visit from him for a cuppa from time to time, which was very exciting as his big black state car rolled into the farm. He was a great man, good to my family and many others and never forgot where he came from Now while we are all bright and shiny with a flash name these days I would trade a lot of it for the morals of Frank, who as Premier would at times debate in Parliament with the Opposition and realise they were right and simply say "Well let's do that then". When is the last time you saw that happen these days? I bet Frank, or Sir Francis as he was knighted on retirement, never left anyone wondering where he stood on matters. Yes, take me "way back when" to that. RIVERS were fundamental to the development of the region.
